meta.title: Jason Chaney | Professional Web Application Development

root.intro: I am a seasoned web developer that adheres to the highest level of semantic standards and architectures. I have over 13 years of cutting-edge experience working for agencies, direct clients, companies and individuals. My passion is rooted in finding efficiency in digital communication though visual arts. I have experience leading distributed development teams, executing social campaigns, utilizing/building web services, prototyping new concepts, developing mobile initiatives and optimizing workflows.

about.title: Who is this Guy?
about.subtitle: I'm a full-stack front-end developer.

culture.title: My Culture
culture.body: The techniques, tools and architecture patterns used to create the modern web literally change everyday. As a professional developer, I consider it my responsibility to constantly keep up. I listen to podcasts, follow industry leaders on Twitter and collaborate with other professionals daily to ensure I'm using the absolute latest resources available when project crunch time hits.

about.body: I specialize in building responsive, mobile-first interactive solutions. I focus on usability and architecture while ensuring code conforms to the highest level of web and OOP semantic standards. I enjoy keeping up with bleeding-edge tools, techniques and new technologies. Check out my process to hear how.

dad.title: Dad
dad.body: I have two beautiful twin daughters that keep my wife and I on our toes. We keep a family blog for friends and family to keep up with the Chaney's antics.

technology.title: Technology
technology.body: I enjoy making tutorials for other developers, hacking a baby swing, pulling my kids behind my Segway or learning new technologies like Codeception.

code.title: Code
code.body: I love all things code. Finding new ways to optimize a method, app, animation or even my monitor setup makes me jump up like Boris in Goldeneye. In fact, this entire site is powered by one data file.

contact.title: Get in Touch
contact.subtitle: If you think I can help out on a project, drop me a line.
contact.name: Jason Chaney

process.title: My Process
process.subtitle: What separates me from other developers?
process.body: If you ask a developer what they use to make a website, one might sayDreamweaver, another might say Wordpress or Squarespace and another might say Vim orNode. Just this one answer can tell you tons about the nature of those developers. While it doesn't necessarily provide a way to know which one might be more skilled at software architecture, it does tell you which one probably has more knowledge that reaches beyond the average script-kiddies.
process.asside: I have talked to many developers who say they know JavaScript, when in fact what they really know is how to modify jQuery code. What I do here is outline the general approach and tools I use for interactive project construction. This should give you a good idea as to the type of developer I am.

point.headline: The Editor...or rather IDE
point.body:
A good text editor will do things like syntax highlighting. A great editor will do things like code completion. But an awesome editor is not an editor at all, It's an IDE
or Integrated Development Environment. Some common IDE's areEclipse, Apple'sxCode, Flash Builder (Built on Eclipse), Appcelerator andWebstorm. Personally, I use IntelliJ. The big reason to use an IDE is because text editors like Sublime Text simply understand the piece of code you're writing, but IDE's understand how it all connects. This is an invaluable distinction and can save untold amounts of time both on the development and debugging sides.

point.headline: Build Process
point.body: Websites and apps have grown to a complexity level that they now require more robust techniques for deployment, code optimization and overall organization. The industry standard tool for doing this is Grunt and I love to find ever-efficient ways to build projects for both development and production with it. I use grunt for many tasks including deployment, image optimization, CSS/JS complication, Linting and minifying.

point.headline: Version Control
point.body: Any developer that doesn't use version control doesn't understand the benefits, and therefore probably has not worked in a team environment or on extremely large projects and is most likely still FTPing files around. I take version control one step further. Not only do I use theGit version control system, I also run my own Git server withGitolite. Many people who aren't able to run their own server also use Github which works really well too. If I am stuck dealing with FTP, I'll use something like Dandelion if Rsync or Git deployment is unavailable.

point.headline: Pre-compilers
point.body: Every developer is going to say they know CSS. What this really means, is that they understand how to position and style DOM elements. Once again, I take this further. I use Sass to organize, optimize and generate cross-device/browser code. I also incorporate CSS3 transitions and transforms over JS whenever possible to take advantage of the accelerated performance. What this means for a client, is simply that I create more organized code and faster load times.

point.headline: CSS Resetting
point.body: I use HTML5 Boilerplate to ensure that CSS is as consistent as possible when starting a project. Technically, I use a custom repo first started with Initializr which includes HTML5 Boilerplate, Twitter's Bootstrap and a few others.

point.headline: Browser testing
point.body: I use Parallels Desktop and sometimes Virtual Box with Windows XP and 7 to test IE6-9. Chrome, Firefox, iOS and Safari are tested on the Mac side. I also use a few Andriod tablets and the iOS simulator.

point.headline: Mobile styling and functionality
point.body: What happens when a project is viewed on a mobile device? Suffice it to say it's a major consideration on projects I work on. I'm intimately familiar with Apple's iOS developer guidelines for mobile web development. Many developers don't consider Webclips or High-PPI screens. I do.

point.headline: JavaScript
point.body: Most developers are going to say they know JavaScript but since JavaScript is a separate art in it's own right, I encourage prospective clients to understand the level that someone really knows JavaScript. I don't simply modify JavaScript or use a framework like JQuery. I write custom JavaScript that follows the MVC design pattern utilizing Backbone.js andJQuery. If you're interested in developing a polished site or application which includes as much AJAX functionality as you can muster, you must develop in a way that allows you to organize large quantities of code. Mixing data into the DOM is a great way to have parts of your site fail when it reaches a high complexity level. When I say I know JavaScript, I really know it.

point.headline: RequireJS
point.body: It's important to make sure that all script files are loaded and loaded in a specific order. I use require.js for this function. If you're a developer and are using a ton of JavaScript files on your project, I encourage you to start using a module loader like RequireJS as it will help you improve the quality and speed of your code.

point.headline: API
point.body: Many projects require pushing and pulling content from a database. Good developers will write clean code to interface with the database. Great developers will use an ORM tool so they can simply write less code to interface with the database. Awesome developers will create an API (with a REST interface) to utilize an ORM tool so other sites, web services and applications can access data. Truly exceptional developers take it one step even further and use a REST server. Many people will look at this and say the good developer that just writes clean code to interface with the database directly is all their project needs so why spend time (thus money) doing all that? What they wouldn't realize is that it's actually faster to develop with these tools. Using a REST API and ORM tool is faster, cleaner, more maintainable and extensible than interfacing with the database directly so there's really no reason not to go that route except one. Knowledge.

point.headline: ORM
point.body:
I'll spare you from the technobabble but basically an ORM tool allows you to write a lot less code to work with a database to accomplish the exact same things. It also helps keep things organized. Personally, I use either RedbeanPHP or the native active record pattren
syntax found in many frameworks like CodeIgniter.

point.headline: Templating
point.body: For large-scale deployments, I use both Twig and on the JavaScript side,JQuery templates. On mid to small projects or projects where other team members may not be familiar with those, I'll usually just use the templating tool that's part of whatever framework is being used.

point.headline: REST Server
point.body: I like CodeIgniter's controllers for creating most APIs as it's one of the fastest in terms of performance but I will also sometimes use a modified rest server originally created by Jacob Wright that uses PHP introspection to map HTTP requests as defined in code comments to specific class methods. The server is also responsible for translating and escaping data to JSON as well and managing the various HTTP verbs (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE and UPDATE).

point.headline: JQuery
point.body: If you're reading this, you likely already know what JQuery is since it's now on more than half of all websites, but if you don't, it's basically a tool (framework) to write less JavaScript and have that JavaScript function consistently across platforms. I use JQuery extensively in most interactive projects but can drop down to Javascript syntax if need be. I also write custom JQuery plugins occasionally should one unlikely not exist.

point.headline: Debugging Tools
point.body: I useCharles Proxy, Firebug and Deltawalker in addition to the IDE. You can find out what each of these are via the links. When something doesn't work right, you want someone who can find out why and find out quickly.

point.headline: Documentation
point.body: Any good developer will comment their code for others. I also useMarkdown, Omnigraffle, and wikis to help document code should it make sense on a project.

point.headline: Working Locally
point.body:
I use MAMP Pro to create virtual machines and map development URLs to local vhosts. In a nutshell, I create projects on my computer before I push them up to a staging or live production server. How do I push them up? FTP is slow and insecure so I use a Git post-hook to keep production, stage and dev locations in sync with remote repos. In layman's terms, that means I can update a site with a single click and that update happens faster and in such a way that's easy to fix should a file get narfed by someone else. If you are a developer and would like to read more specifics, you can check out
how we do it.

point.headline: Database Management
point.body: I use Navicat and the CLI to manage my databases. For those wondering, it would replace the need for PHPMyAdmin when using a GUI.

point.headline: Issue Tracking
point.body: I've used a few tools including Jira and Lighthouse but perferYouTrack. If you'd like to know why, justask.

point.headline: Video Fallbacks
point.body:
I'm still looking for a preference but I generally use a JavaScript library like the Kartura Media Library
to provide Flash replacement to HTML5 video if the video element is unsupported. This ensures that video and audio content is compatible on all devices and platforms.

point.headline: Speed
point.body:
I'd like to end this with one more point. If you hand off a comp (a layered Photoshop file) for a developer to bring to life, will they separate out each multi-layer element as a separate image with 2 or less clicks? Do you want someone knowledgeable about time-savers likethis? I'm always looking for more efficient ways to do things.
If you value that, let's chat.

process.close: As you can see, there are many aspects and tools to creating the rich interactive experiences that people expect. It's important to make sure that you know when and how to use them. Not using these tools, means development will take longer, cost more, be harder to maintain in the future and is generally more prone to fail. As a prospective client, you'll need to decide who you want to hire for your project.

portfolio.title: My Kung Fu
portfolio.subtitle: These are for you.
portfolio.body: Here's some examples of projects I've had the privilege of working on for various clients.

oneoffs.responsive: I specialize in mobile web development. I'm keenly aware of often overlooked details such as IE10's snap mode, handling pointer/touch events correctly, GPU accelerated animation, and mobile-first Sass techniques.
oneoffs.fullstack: I'm a full stack front end developer which means I work the entire development verticle. I use Bower , Composer , Grunt , PHP , MongoDB , NodeJS , Backbone, RequireJS , and web sericve APIs.
